What do new teachers, librarians and school psychologists have in common? They all attend new staff orientation just before the school year starts.

Newly-hired school staff members Kylie Mathis-Wadsworth (Highland special education), Evan Kohler (J.T. Waugh physical education), and Kelly Reigle (A.J. Schmidt school psychologist) on Monday joined three other recently-hired teachers (Deanna Civilette and Erin Eno, High School music; Tracy Wing, A.J. Schmidt library-media) to get acquainted with building principals and veteran staff members who will be their mentors throughout the school year. The orientation also covered trauma-informed instruction and Charlotte Danielson's "A Framework for Teaching." The orientation continued today with a virtual orientation from the Seneca Nation of Indians Department of Education. The session covered Seneca Nation culture, language, history and government. It also included a history of Seneca Education (Thomas Indian School) and a virtual tour of the Territory.

Within the first hour on Monday, Food Service Director Debbie Becker distributed 145 grab-and-go meals at the J.T. Waugh pick up center. The meals are provided to any Lake Shore child up to the age of 18. Pick up is Mondays and Thursdays, from 9:30-11 am. The Monday pick up provides breakfast and lunch for Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday. Thursday pick up provides breakfast and lunch for Thursday and Friday and the weekend. Mrs. Becker, from Personal Touch Food Service, says the breakfast includes cereal and an item that can be warmed up, like a cinnamini or French toast. Lunches may include chicken nuggets, chicken patties, or tacos. Fruit and vegetable servings also are included, as well as juice and milk.

Pickup locations are at JT Waugh Elementary School, 100 High St., Angola, and the ECLS on the Seneca Nation Territory from 9:30 to 11 am.

We hope this provides our community with some relief over the summer.

Calling All Eaglets!
Parents, UPK Registration is underway! You can pick up a registration packet at the William T. Hoag Educational Center, 42 Sunset Blvd., Angola.
Here's the scoop:
To be enrolled in the September 2020 Universal Pre-Kindergarten class, a child living in the Lake Shore Central School district must be four years old on or before December 1, 2020.

Proof of age is required at the time of registration. (A birth certificate, baptismal record, or passport will serve as adequate proof.) Also, an official record of immunizations and proof of district residency are required.

All immunizations must be acquired by the start of school in September. (Students without required immunizations will not be permitted to start school.)

We will have a UPK Visitation – parents and entering students will be invited to visit classrooms and meet the staff before the school year starts.

Call us at 926-2480 if you have questions. We look forward to having you!

Sharing a project today from an Alden 8th grader.
Kiersten is in a program called the Envision Experience, where participants learn about leadership while discovering their passions. They're required to create a product that makes an impact on other people's lives. COVID-19 derailed many plans for sharing the projects, but we can help share her short video highlighting plastic pollution and what individuals can do to help. There's some beautiful photography and the message that sticks is that "Plastic doesn't disappear; it just moves around." Boy, does it move around. As we enjoy the beauty of spring, hers is a timely reminder on how to keep it beautiful.

Ever consider how a famous work of art might look if you redid it with just stuff around the house? High School art teacher Kathryn Zittel posed the question and 41 people - students, faculty, and community members - responded. The result is this gallery of art recreations in Lake Shore's Great Masters Challenge, patterned after an initiative of the Getty Museum. Here we have Piet Mondrian's 'Composition in Red, Blue, Yellow and Black' reconstructed with folded squares of colored t-shirts. Emanuel Leutze's 'Washington Crosses the Delaware' reenacted with two kids and their teddy bears sailing on furniture across the living room. The ruffled collar of Frans Pourbus's 'The Elders' reconstructed as a collar of bananas. Pierre-August Renoir's 'The Luncheon of the Boating Party' restaged with family around a kitchen table. They are earnest, funny, clever, somber ... and each in their own way immensely creative and engaging. Browse the gallery here:
https://drive.google.com/file/d/1rLE0yqyu0aI5N0zAeDUUfCOcWiKOcv7G/view?usp=sharing
#gettymuseumchallenge
#betweenartandquarantine

Did you catch that helicopter buzzing over Highland and surrounding neighborhoods today?
It was something special for the kids who came with their parents to district elementary schools this morning for a “drive through” pick up of belongings left behind when schools abruptly closed in March.

Piloting the helicopter were Erie County Sheriff's Department Captain Kevin Caffery (semi-retired) and his copilot, Deputy Sean Young. Both have a deep connection with the schools. Captain Caffery’s kids attended A.J. Schmidt and his wife taught at district elementary schools and his mother-in-law was a teacher’s aide at A.J. Schmidt. Deputy Young’s kids attend J.T Waugh Elementary School.

They know what a strange and unexpected year this has been.

Their ‘shout out’ from above was something fun and a gesture of solidarity to all who had to quickly adjust to a very different kind of school year and now begin the wind down to year’s end and whatever ‘new normal’ the Fall may bring.

Here are some photos of the Highland flyover.

Because the basketball end-of-year dinner could not be held this year, Coach Lyford has been honoring a senior a day: "Our captain Zach Evans finishes up our senior tribute. Zach was our team leader both on and off the floor. He is a true student athlete and was chosen as a NYSPHSAA scholar athlete. "He was also our steals leader w/34. Z is a natural born leader with tremendous skills. He developed into a dominant player and was rewarded with being named to the ECIC III 1st team as well as our team MVP. Zach, I'll never forget your buzzer beater vs E.A.
"Z is a 3 sport athlete who excels in both volleyball and baseball as well. It's impossible to replace a player like Zach but hopefully our underclassmen have learned from his examples. Good luck at NCCC next year, they are receiving a great young man. Thank you Zach!" #family

For today's TIP for TEACHING at HOME, we are sharing important advice from Homeland Security Investigations.

As you know, since the closing of schools due to COVID-19, school work and communications are happening online. Please be aware that predators who stalk the Internet have not taken a break during COVID-19. Homeland Security Investigations reminds parents that your supervision, open discussions about Internet safety, active monitoring, and use of privacy settings will reduce the chance of victimization.

Please see https://www.lakeshorecsd.org to review the Internet Safety Tips from Homeland Security Investigations.

So she may choose her Monday to look like:

9:20 Math
9:40 Reading
10:00 Technology
10:20 Snack
10:40 Writing
11:00 Science
11:20 Art
11:40 Lunch

9:00 P.E.
9:20 Science
9:40 Reading
10:00 Art
10:20 Snack
10:40 Math
11:00 Writing
11:20 Technology
11:40 Lunch

I find because she had the opportunity to make her own schedule it's easier to get through the schedule."

Today's TIP for TEACHING at HOME is from Misty Kerl, Middle School science teacher:
Choose 1 or 2 subjects a day. Try to accomplish as much as you can on those days. Ignore the other subjects' assignments & emails & REMIND messages until the day you've chosen for those subjects...then check those things out. (DON'T delete the messages, just refer to them when it’s their turn, so to speak)
Also, at least for me...have your child keep in touch with the teacher of each subject. We're waiting to hear from them. (NOTE: I am a middle school teacher and only teach one subject, so my class is different than an elementary teacher.)

Here is the link to ALL the tips: https://www.lakeshorecsd.org/cms/lib/NY19001770/Centricity/Domain/4/Tips%20for%20Home.pdf

If you are without health insurance due to COVID-19-related job loss, please read this ... and please share if you know someone who may need this information!

With the recent closure of businesses across the state, many New York State residents are at risk of losing health insurance coverage as a result of COVID-19.

If you have lost your health insurance, you may be eligible for health coverage with financial assistance through the NY State of Health due to your loss of coverage or income. Because of loss of income, New Yorkers may also be eligible for Medicaid, the Essential Plan, Child Health Plus, or subsidized Qualified Health Plan coverage.

A Special Enrollment Period is now open. If you have lost employer coverage, you must apply within 60 days of losing that coverage.

Visit www.nystateofhealth.ny.gov for help finding a health care plan that works for you. For additional questions, call 518-486-9102 or email NYSOH@health.ny.gov.

There were 56 successful donations, and that translates into
168 lives saved, thanks to Lake Shore High School's March blood drive. Blood drives are a long-standing tradition at the High School and, thanks to students, staff and community members, they have been very successful.
With school buildings now closed, no further blood drives are scheduled at LSCSD buildings. Blood drives scheduled for April 7 at We Rock the Spectrum Kids' Gym and April 9 at St. John's Lutheran Church have reached capacity with donor appointments ... but, the need is more urgent than ever amid a current blood shortage due to COVID-19.
Please support the upcoming EMERGENCY blood drives as they are announced in our communities. Thank you!
Among the LSHS students donating blood at the High School were Kira Fleming and Joe Wasielewski. Great job, everybody!

He is only the third Lake Shore wrestler to place in the state championship. 😎

Way to go, Julian! 🙌

The 2020 Census is almost here 😱🎉

Help Lake Shore Central Schools get the funds we deserve by completing the Census and accurately counting all of the children in your household!

According to the NYS Education Department, the census is responsible for approximately $6.7 billion in funding and children are often under-reported.

That means less funding goes towards important programs that serve our youth!

Who's ready for Dr. Suess's birthday? 1st graders in Mrs. Serena's class at Highland Elementary School are! Dr. Suess's Birthday is a nationwide reading celebration that takes place annually on March 2nd. It's a day to celebrate reading all over the United States ... and certainly at Highland.
Born in 1904, Dr. Suess would be 116 if he were alive today. His stories live on in homes and classrooms everywhere. Special thanks to Southtowns Christian Center for ordering a water purifier and replacement filters that will purify up to 18,000 gallons of water. Thank you to everyone for your kindness, generosity and good wishes.

A day in physics class is a day in the study of the universe ... “Physics is a study of the universe and the laws that govern it," says LSHS physic teacher Jeff Salerno. “Physics is motion, acceleration, energy, waves, color, sound, light, electricity, fluids, thermodynamics, the nucleus, and the list goes on.”
In a recent class, his students were beginning their understanding of electricity, current, voltage, and resistance.

What did you do over spring break? The cast of "Annie, Jr." used the time to rehearse so they're all set for opening night this Thursday, Feb. 27 at 7 p.m. at Lake Shore Middle School. Additional performances are at 7 p.m., Friday and Saturday, Feb. 28 and 29. Tickets are $5.
"Annie, Jr." is the 60-minute version of the show with songs and keys changed to ranges appropriate for Middle School-age voices. Whatever key the story is in, it's the same irrepressible heroine who will steal your heart with her "pluck and positivity"! 7th grader Ella Barrett is Annie, with Gus Barrett as Sandy, and 8th grader Benson Quinn as Mr. Warbucks. 7th grader Max Hazard is Bert Healy and 8th grader Reilly Green is Grace. Carissa Littlejohn directs.
Enjoy the show!
